thread.title: Training-camp time for your portfolio
thread.title_full: Training-camp time for your portfolio | The Seattle Times

author: Chuck Jaffe
title: Training-camp time for your portfolio
text:
Your Funds Mutual funds are always in season so they never go through training camp.
But as football teams are now preparing for the season ahead, so should investors be looking to get their team of funds into fighting trim.
That’s especially true now as investors worry about what might happen when the Federal Reserve finally raises interest rates and changes the environment that market has been playing in for years.
Putting your portfolio through its training-camp paces helps an investor decide what’s worth holding onto and whether cutting a player or making a trade can make the entire team stronger.
 Boy hurt in fall at Taylor Swift concert at CenturyLink Moreover, with the market seemingly in flux and the bull market wavering, it’s a good time for investors — acting as owner, general manager and coach of their team of funds — to review their game plan and approach to the game of money management.
Here are the elements that coaches focus on at training camp that investors should be looking at now:
• Makeup of the team: Obviously teams need players at every position, and investors need the same kind of coverage to make up the core of a portfolio.
You don’t need funds that fit into every checkoff on a style box — that would force an investor to have nine stock and nine bond funds at a minimum, making a portfolio unwieldy — but you need building blocks on offense and defense.
Consider your core stock funds the offensive players and core bond funds to be your defense.
That said, core funds are cornerstones, preferably with a history of above-average returns and below-average costs.
Make sure they maintain that status; a coach watches how players recover from injury, for example, while an investor should see how a fund copes with a manager change.
This is a good time to review performance on a relative basis; make sure the funds on your team are keeping up at their position, in their asset class.
• How you want to play offense: A coach decides if the offense will take a grind-it-out, move-the-chains approach, or if it will be a higher-risk, higher-reward take-chances passing game.
The art comes in finding the right balance, one that you can live with when it’s not necessarily scoring touchdowns or when the opposition — which in this case is the stock market — makes it particularly tough to gain yards. Too often, investors wind up with too much overlap, holding several large-cap funds or only value funds. That’s basically committing to the run, or the long bomb; when the defense is stacked up against your strength, you’re not going anywhere.
• How you want to play defense: For most investors, bond funds are the defensive play, so seeing how they could play now — as bond funds tend to react negatively to rate increases, at least initially — is important.
Investors have been focused on defense ever since the financial crisis of 2008, and now have portfolios that are often heavier into bonds than expected.
The opponent of your defense is the economy, interest rates and the market, and with an increase in rates, bond funds will face new challenges.
This is where an investor who is worried about a market downturn can add options, whether that is income-oriented stock funds, corporates, junk or convertible-securities funds, bear-market funds, and more, hoping to further diversify and make the defense more flexible.
• Focus on special teams: The buzzword in the fund industry for the last few years has been “alternative,” and while that generally refers to asset classes beyond stocks, bonds and cash, it has become parlance for specialized funds using complex hedge-fund strategies trying to make money in all market conditions.
Alt funds are not a “must,” in an average investor’s fund portfolio, but for anyone who has a solid offense and stalwart defense, the third-phase of the game can help to improve overall performance. Decide how important you want this to be in your planning.
• Game-planning: This is where current market conditions, plus your time horizon and risk tolerances, come most into play.
You may simply rebalance the portfolio — culling winners and putting your portfolio back onto plan — if you’re confident the strategy will continue working, or you could change allocations based on market conditions or personal changes, like making the portfolio more conservative as you age rather than sticking with the approach you used when first putting together a few decades ago.
How do you upgrade the team? Unlike pro sports teams, it’s easy to make trades for your fund team. If you believe there’s a better option out there — or that you are paying opportunity costs by investing in a mediocre fund or a laggard — you can make a swap.
That said, be sure to examine any applicable tax costs before making a move. You’re not improving your overall portfolio if the upgrade to your portfolio can’t also recoup any taxes you have to pay in short order.
Armed with a new and/or confirmed roster of players, it’s game on. You should be ready for whatever the market dishes out next.
